title: Ebo Taylor: Shaping Highlife Music and Global Influence
summary: Ebo Taylor, a Ghanaian guitarist, composer, and band leader, passed away at 90, leaving a legacy that defined the highlife genre. Born in Cape Coast in 1936, he gained prominence in the late 1950s and 1960s as highlife became Ghana's dominant music. Over six decades, Taylor fused Ghanaian rhythms with jazz, funk, soul, and Afrobeat, influencing musicians across Africa and beyond. He played with leading bands like the Stargazers and Broadway Dance Band, developing a distinctive guitar style. In later years, his music was rediscovered globally, with tracks like Love & Death attracting new fans. Taylor studied music in London in the 1960s, collaborating with Fela Kuti, which helped shape Afrobeat. He returned to Ghana as a sought-after producer and arranger, working with artists like Pat Thomas. He also taught at the University of Ghana and continued recording into old age. His influence extended through sampling in hip-hop and R&B, making him a key figure in world music.

background_read: Ebo Taylor was a pivotal figure in Ghanaian music, emerging during a time when highlife was becoming the country's main musical form. Highlife originated in Ghana in the early 20th century, combining local Akan rhythms with Western instruments like guitars and brass. Taylor's career spanned the evolution of African music, from traditional sounds to global genres like Afrobeat. His studies in London exposed him to international styles, allowing him to innovate. The collaboration with Fela Kuti highlights the cross-cultural exchanges that shaped modern African music. Taylor's later work in education and production shows his dedication to nurturing talent, while sampling in contemporary music demonstrates his enduring relevance in the digital age.
